intro: Sisyrinchium bracteatum, commonly known as the bracteate blue-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Iridaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, grass-like foliage and showy blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun, making it well adapted to arid environments. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Sisyrinchium bracteatum is often used in xeriscaping due to its low water requirements and ornamental value.
